Synthesis, structure and catalytic activity of the supported Ni catalysts for highly efficient one-step hydrogenation of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene to 1,5-diaminodecahydronaphthalene X.-H. Lu X.-L. Wei D. Zhou ⁎ H.-Z. Jiang Y.-W. Sun Q.-H. Xia ⁎ Hubei Collaborative Innovation Center for Advanced Organic Chemical Materials, Ministry-of-Education Key Laboratory for the Synthesis and Applications of Organic Functional Molecules, Hubei University, Wuhan 430062, Hubei, China Hubei Collaborative Innovation Center for Advanced Organic Chemical Materials, Ministry-of-Education Key Laboratory for the Synthesis and Applications of Organic Functional Molecules, Hubei University Wuhan Hubei 430062 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 27 50865387; fax: +86 27 88663043. Graphical abstract Highly efficient catalytic hydrogenation of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene with nitro groups and aromatic rings to 1,5-diaminodecahydronaphthalene is carried out over the supported Ni catalysts through one-step reaction strategy. A series of the supported nickel catalysts have been synthesized through impregnation, characterized by X-ray diffraction, N2 sorption measurement, temperature programmed H2 reduction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The morphology and particle size of catalysts are imaged by scanning electron microscope. The catalysts have efficiently catalyzed the one-step hydrogenation of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene to 1,5-diaminodecahydronaphthalene. The catalyst 10%Ni/SiO2-1a is the most active for the titled hydrogenation with 100mol% conversion and 95.3% selectivity, applicable for the catalytic one-step hydrogenation of nitro-aromatic compounds. The reducibility of NiO species on different supports has been carefully studied. Some factors such as the type of carriers, the addition of modifiers, the silica source, the Ni loading, the H2 pressure and the reaction temperature and time play important roles in controlling the hydrogenation. In addition, the negative effect of the water amount has been observed. The recycling tests reveal the recyclability and stability of the supported Ni catalyst. Keywords Catalytic one-step hydrogenation Nitro groups Aromatic rings The supported Ni catalysts 1,5-Dinitronaphthalene 1 Introduction The cycloaliphatic amines are important organic chemicals and intermediates, widely used in the manufacturing of rubber chemicals, food additives, pharmaceuticals, and isocyanates. Alicyclic isocyanates without aromatic rings exhibit a strong light stability; therefore, this kind of isocyanates is favorable for preparing anti-yellowing polyurethane products. Owing to ever-increasing applications of polyurethane products, the demand for high quality alicyclic isocyanates is ever growing. This means that the synthesis of cycloaliphatic amines has become imperative. The catalytic hydrogenation of nitro aromatics to aromatic amines is a very important reaction. The catalytic reduction with molecular hydrogen carries many advantages, such as clean production process, high atom economy, easy operation, easy product separation, and high selectivity to the desired products [1,2]. In industrial processes, the catalytic conversion from nitro aromatics to alicyclic amines will undergo ‘two-step’ reaction processes, i.e. the reduction of nitro aromatics to aromatic amines, and of aromatic amines to alicyclic ones by H2. Up to now, the catalytic hydrogenation has been one of the most commonly used methods for the preparation of cycloaliphatic amines from aromatic ones. Homogeneous catalysts are highly active, but their preparation and separation recycling are relatively difficult, so heterogeneous ones have attracted more attention. The developed heterogeneous catalysts mainly include the supported precious metal (Pt, Pd, Ru and alloys) catalysts [3–6], or non-noble metal (raney Ni and amorphous alloy) catalysts [7,8], in which the supports are oxides, polymers or activated carbon. So far, many catalytic hydrogenation reactions have been conducted in gas phase [9–11] or liquid phase [12–15], which involve the use of heterogeneous transition metal catalysts, such as Pd [16], Pt [17], Rh [18], Ir [19], Ni [20–22], raney Ni [23], Au [24], Ru [25] or poly-metallic catalysts [26,27]. However, most of the catalysts are still expensive. The supported nickel catalysts have been widely applied in industrially important chemical processes, such as hydrogenation/dehydrogenation, methanation, reforming, hydrocracking and so on [28–30]. To obtain the supported nickel catalysts with high activity, some approaches and techniques have been developed, in which aqueous chelated metal complexes [31–34] and organic nickel precursors [35] are supported by a wet impregnation and directly reduced with hydrogen without calcination in air [36]. For the catalytic hydrogenation of aromatic amine to alicyclic one, nickel-based Ni–Al catalysts are commonly used. However, these Ni–Al catalysts show a narrow activation temperature (generally 130–180°C), and a low selectivity of fully hydrogenated alicyclic amines. The drawbacks are mainly correlated with high nickel content and low dispersion on the carrier, so reducing the nickel content and improving the effective utilization are of particular importance. Meanwhile, in the catalytic hydrogenation reaction, the solvent has a great influence on the reaction rate and selectivity. Some studies have concluded that [37,38], for the similar structures solvent, the solubility of hydrogen in the solvent may affect the rate of heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation, and the solvent may affect the adsorption of hydrogen on the catalyst surface in the catalytic hydrogenation reaction. To date, only one report has approached highly selective ‘one-step’ catalytic hydrogenation from nitro aromatics to alicyclic amines [39], which can completely skip the synthesis, separation and transformation of aromatic amine intermediates, and meet the requirements of energy-saving green chemistry. The present work reports the synthesis, structure and catalytic activity of the supported Ni catalysts for highly efficient one-step liquid phase hydrogenation of nitro-aromatic compounds with nitro groups and aromatic rings. The present study is focused on the catalytic hydrogenation from 1,5-dinitronaphathlene to 1,5-diaminodecahydronaphathlene. Under optimal conditions, almost 100mol% of the substrate conversion with a high selectivity of the product up to 95.3% is achieved over the most active catalyst, which is encouraging. Furthermore, some factors affecting the reaction are revealed through conducting a number of reactions and wide characterizations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Raney Ni (99.5%), Ni (NO3)2·6H2O (98%), RuCl3·xH2O (Ru 48–42%), PdCl2 (Pd 59–60%), Al2O3 (98%), TiO2 (99%), C (activated carbon) (97%) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Chemical Co. The sesbania powder (98%) was purchased from Shangdong Dongming Sesbania Gum Factory and n-octyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (98%) was purchased from Wuhan wdsilicone Co. The main reagent used in the hydrogenations were 1,5-dinitronaphthalene (99.0%, Shanghai) was directly used as received. The freshly distilled solvents included methanol, dioxane, ethyl acetate, tetrahydrofuran (THF) and cyclohexane. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts A solution of Ni (NO3)2·6H2O or precious metal chlorides was impregnated onto various supports like γ-Al2O3, TiO2, activated carbon, three SiO2 sources (aerosil-200 silica, Ludox AS-40 and Ludox HS-40 colloidal silica), and modified aerosil-200 silica with modifiers. Note that γ-Al2O3 was obtained by calcining pseudoboehmite precursor in air at 550°C for 2h. The supported catalysts were prepared through the following procedure. Typically, 2g of aerosil-200 silica was dispersed into the solution consisted of Ni (NO3)2·6H2O (1.082g) and distilled water (30g). Then, to the above mixture, one solution of 0.27g sesbania powder dissolved in 20ml of ethanol was slowly dripped while stirring. Subsequently, the resulting mixture was heated to 70–80°C accompanied by stirring, until water had been completely evaporated off. The green solid was dried at 100°C for 12h, calcined at 400°C for 3h in the flow of air, and then reduced by hydrogen at 400°C for 3h in a tubular reactor. The resultant catalyst was designated as 10%Ni/SiO2-1a, in which the nickel content was 10wt% determined by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis, or 10wt% by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis. Using a similar procedure, nickel or other metals was impregnated onto the supports inclusive of three SiO2 sources, γ-Al2O3, SiO2–Al2O3 (1:1), TiO2 or activated carbon. Finally, the dried samples were calcined at given temperatures for 3h in the flowing air, and then reduced by hydrogen at desired temperatures for 3h. The resultant catalysts were designated as n%M/SiO2-1–3 (silica sources: 1—aerosil-200 silica, 2—Ludox AS-40 colloidal silica, 3—Ludox HS-40 colloidal silica), n%M/Al2O3, n%M/SiO2–Al2O3, n%M/TiO2, n%M/C, where n% was the weight percent of metals. The 10%Ni/SiO2-1 modified with four modifiers (a—sesbania powder, b—activated carbon, c— n-octyltrimethylammonium bromide, d—glucose) was designated as 10%Ni/SiO2-1a, -1b, -1c, -1d, respectively. The XRF results have shown that the Ni content of all 10%Ni/oxides catalysts prepared by impregnation method are in the range of 9.95–10.0wt%. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out using a Rigaku D/MAX-IIIC diffractometer with Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation operating at 30kV and 25mA. The scanning conditions were as follows: divergence slit, 1.0 (°); scattering slit, 1.0 (°); receiving slit, 0.3 (mm); scanning range, 5–65° 2θ; scanning speed, 2°/min. Autosorb-1 was used to determine the N2 adsorption–desorption properties of the samples. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area was calculated using the BET equation in the relative pressure between 0.05 and 0.25. The Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method was used to calculate the pore volume. Prior to the measurements, the samples were degassed at 300°C under a vacuum of 10−2 mbar for 10h. The morphology and size of crystals were imaged with a JEOL JSM-6510A scanning electron microscope (SEM). The temperature programmed H2 reduction (TPR) was carried out in a N2 flow of 50ml/min (10vol% H2), from room temperature to 600°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to monitor the H2 consumption. Before starting the TPR procedure, the sample was pretreated at 200°C for 30min in a N2 flow of 100ml/min and then cooled down to room temperature. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded on a VG ESCALAB MK II spectrometer, using a monochromatic Mg-Kα radiation, operating at a constant transmission energy pass (80eV). The C1s photoelectron peak (binding energy of 284.6eV with an accuracy of ±0.05eV) was used as an energy reference. Shirley background was subtracted in the least-square fitting. The peak shape was fixed to a mixture of 20% Lorentzian and 80% Gaussian with an asymmetric parameter of 0. 2.4 Catalytic activity test The catalytic one-step hydrogenations of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene (1,5-DNN) with nitro groups and aromatic rings to 1,5-diaminodecahydronaphthalene (1,5-DADHN) were carried out in a batch autoclave (100ml) under desired temperatures and H2 pressures. As illustrated in Scheme 1 , the hydrogenated products were mainly consisted of 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (1,5-DAN), 1,5-DADHN, and others (some cracked byproducts). The reactant 1,5-DNN (1.0g) was dissolved in the solvent (methanol, dioxane, ethyl acetate, THF or cyclohexane) (9.0g) under magnetic stirring (the stirring rate of 250r/min), to which the reduced catalyst (100mg) was added. Once the desired temperature and pressure was reached, the reaction was thought to start. Several hours later, the reaction was stopped, then the reactor was cooled down to ambient temperature and H2 was released. The solid catalyst was then recovered by filtration, washed several times with tetrahydrofuran (THF) and dried for next use. The liquid filtrate was quantitatively analyzed by GC-2010 equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a DB-1 capillary column (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm), where hydrogen was used as carrier gas. For the sake of comparison, the catalytic hydrogenation of 1,5-DAN to 1,5-DADHN was conducted as well. In order to obtain the corresponding hydrogenation products from the reaction mixture, the crude reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo and purified by column chromatography. In the latter case, the flowing phase was consisted of petroleum ether (b.p. 60–90°C)/ethyl acetate. Yield: 82.6%; M.p.:34.2–36.1°C; 1H-NMR (CDCl3, room temp.) (400MHz): 1.13–1.91 (m, 7H, alicyclic protons), 1.93 (s, 2H, NH2), 2.56 (s, 1H, CHNH2); 13C CP MAS NMR (CH3OD) (100MHz): δ =25.21, 32.12, 34.81, 44.37, 48.92. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characteristics of catalysts Fig. 1 presents the XRD patterns of the samples with different Ni loadings, in which no peaks due to the support of Al2O3 or SiO2 can be seen, implying that SiO2 or Al2O3 exists as poorly crystalline phases. And, the XRD patterns of the used supports have been added in the supporting information (Fig. S1). The XRD peaks of the reduced Ni particles at 2θ =44.4°, 51.6° and 75.9° are visible for the supported Ni samples with the Ni loading of 10wt%, except for 10%Ni/SiO2–Al2O3. The XRD patterns of three 10%Ni/SiO2, 10%Ni/Al2O3 and 10%Ni/TiO2 samples show three [111], [200] and [220] diffraction peaks of Ni0 observed at 44.4, 51.6 and 75.9°, but that of 10%Ni/SiO2–Al2O3 only shows a [111] diffraction peak of Ni0. The particle size decreases from 26 to 6nm according to the Scherrer equation. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of NiO/SiO2-1a (precursor of 10%Ni/SiO2-1a) calcined at different temperatures. Below 300°C, the NiO diffraction peaks are broad and weak; above 400°C, those peaks become narrow and intense, indicating the increase of the grain size of NiO species. Table 1 list the BET surface areas and total pore volumes of various catalysts determined by the BET analysis. Very clearly, the BET surface areas and pore volumes of the support TiO2 and the catalyst 10%Ni/TiO2 are the smallest. Other supports and the corresponding catalysts possess large BET surface areas and total pore volumes. Both values of the catalyst 10%Ni/C (activated carbon as the support) are the largest. Especially, the addition of sesbania modifier has led to the increased BET surface area and pore volume from 289m2/g (0.38cm3/g) of 10%Ni/SiO2-1 to 312m2/g (0.45cm3/g) of 10%Ni/SiO2-1a, obviously larger than those of 10%Ni/SiO2-1b, 10%Ni/SiO2-1c, and 10%Ni/SiO2-1d modified with other modifiers. Fig. 3 shows the N1s and Ni2p XPS spectra of the samples 10%Ni/SiO2-1a and the precursor NiO/SiO2-1a (unreduced). The upper N1s survey spectra of two samples do not show any obvious peak assignable to the N1s binding energy, indicative of total removal of N-containing species by calcination without any remnant. As can be observed from Fig. 3, one peak emerges at ca. 856.2eV for NiO/SiO2-1a, ascribable to the Ni2p binding energy of Ni2+, without observable Ni3+ species; however, after being reduced by H2, this peak shifts to 857eV, characteristic of the Ni2p binding energy of metallic nickel [40]. Fig. 4 shows the SEM images of the supported Ni catalysts, inclusive of 10%Ni/SiO2-1a, 10%Ni/Al2O3, 10%Ni/SiO2–Al2O3, 10%Ni/TiO2 and 10%Ni/C. As seen from the figure, the SEM images exhibit irregular spherical morphologies of the latter four samples, different from fine particles of 10%Ni/SiO2-1a, on which the supported Ni components are highly dispersed. The sharp boundaries of the particles demonstrate crystalline characteristics of these samples, in which the particle shape and size of different catalysts are decided by the morphology of different carriers, further affecting catalytic activities. The average crystal sizes observed by SEM are 20–30nm for 10%Ni/SiO2-1a, 0.4–1.9μm for 10%Ni/Al2O3, 0.3–1.9μm for 10%Ni/SiO2–Al2O3, 0.3–0.5μm for 10%Ni/TiO2 and 1.3–13.0μm for 10%Ni/C. Fig. 5 shows the SEM images of three 10%Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared from three silica sources. Clearly, uniformly fine particle sizes of 10%Ni/SiO2-1 originating from aerosil-200 silica are obviously smaller than those of 10%Ni/SiO2-2 and 10%Ni/SiO2-3, from which the high activity of the former catalyst is readily understandable. Ranade reported that there were tetrahedrally and octahedrally coordinated Ni2+ species on the supported Ni samples [41], in which the former was less reducible than the latte. The H2-TPR profiles of the supported Ni samples are measured and shown in Fig. 6 , in which the reduction peaks of nickel species appear in the range of 250–550°C. The nickel species reduced at low temperature is attributed to the NiO dispersed on the support; while those reduced at high temperature can be assigned to the NiO interacted strongly with the support, which will form a few surface layers of the support-NiO compounds [21]. The presence of Ni3+ in the sample can be excluded by the absence of the reduction peak at around 200°C [42], in agreement with the XPS result. Thus, in the TPR profile of 10%Ni/SiO2-1 three TPR signals at 302, 362 and 451°C are ascribable to the reduction of NiO particles to metal Ni0 without interaction with the support (at 302°C), to the reduction of Ni2+ with medium interaction (at 362°C), and of Ni2+ with strong interaction with the support (at 451°C). The first TPR reduction peak of the resulting 10%Ni/SiO2-1a shifts to a low temperature of 282°C with the appearance of other three peaks at 340, 406 and 472°C, at which the area of peaks emerging at low reduction temperature of <380°C is predominant. Therefore, the addition of sesbania powder as the modifier promotes the formation of Ni0 particles with a small size, in accordance with the results of XRD patterns and SEM images. H2-TPR profile of 10%Ni/TiO2 shows that the reduction of nickel species on TiO2 occurs in three stages with maximal signals at 326, 371, and 405°C, in which the first reduction peak appears at higher temperature than the former two samples. For the sample 10%Ni/SiO2–Al2O3, a main TPR peak locating at 406°C is observed, together with a very small shoulder at 366°C. According to the literature [21], the main peak at 406°C can be ascribed to the reduction of Ni2+ that interacted with mixed oxides, while the shoulder at 366°C is assigned to the reduction of NiO oxide to metal Ni0. The temperature of the first reduction peak of the catalysts increases in the order of 10%Ni/SiO2-1a<10%Ni/SiO2-1<10%Ni/TiO2 <10%Ni/SiO2–Al2O3, suggesting that the mixed oxide SiO2–Al2O3 as the support will enhance the NiO-support interaction and the reduction difficulty of nickel species. The H2-TPR tests were conducted to determine the chemical state of nickel in 10%Ni/SiO2-1a affected by different calcination temperatures. As shown in Fig. 7 , two main peaks at 308 and 337°C with one shoulder peak at 419°C can be observed in the TPR profile of the sample calcined at 200°C. As the sample is calcined at 400°C, three reduction peaks are visible, in which the TPR peaks below 345°C correspond to the reduction of NiO oxide, and those from 419 to 489°C are assignable to the reduction of Ni2+ having medium to strong interaction with the support. After the sample is calcined above 450°C, the TPR behaviors are further changed, in which only three reduction signals are observed and the first reduction peak shifts to the zone of high temperature. The most likely reason is that the increase of the calcination temperature will gradually enhance the interaction of NiO with the support, further increasing the reduction temperature of NiO species. 3.2 Catalytic one-step hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DADHN over the supported Ni catalysts 3.2.1 Effect of the calcination and reduction temperature The effects of various reaction parameters on the full hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN have been investigated to optimize the reaction conditions. Fig. 8A depicts the effect of the calcination temperatures on the hydrogenation activity of 10%Ni/SiO2-1a. The conversion of 1,5-DNN and the selectivity for 1,5-DADHN show a gradual increase to reach the maxima of 100mol% and 95.3% at 400°C (a conducive temperature to minimize the selectivity of partially-hydrogenated 1,5-DAN) as the calcination temperature is increased from 200 to 400°C, and then a slight decrease as the calcination temperature is continuously increased to 500°C. The H2-TPR tests were conducted to determine the chemical state of nickel in 10%Ni/SiO2-1a affected by different calcination temperatures, as shown in Fig. 7, the best calcination temperature is 400°C. The reduction temperature in the H2 flow exerts a notable impact on the hydrogenation activity of the supported Ni catalysts (e.g. 10%Ni/SiO2-1a). As illustrated in Fig. 8B, the conversion of 1,5-DNN is increased from 35.6 to 100mol% as the reduction temperature of the catalyst is increased from 200 to 400°C. The maxima of 100mol% and 95.3% emerge at 400°C, which is a conducive temperature to minimize the selectivity of partially-hydrogenated 1,5-DAN. A further rise of the reduction temperature to 500°C leads to a small drop of the conversion of 1,5-DNN to 93.6mol% and a big decline of the selectivity for fully-hydrogenated 1,5-DADHN to 78.4%, possibly ascribed to the occurrence of the sintering of Ni metals at the temperature as high as 500°C [43]. 3.2.2 Effect of various reaction conditions Under our experimental conditions, different catalysts have shown a great difference in the catalytic hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DADHN (in Table 2 ). When no catalyst is added, only 10.3mol% of 1,5-DNN is converted with 89.8% selectivity to 1,5-DADHN under 8.5MPa of H2 pressure. Raney Ni catalyst is more active but less selective for the titled full-hydrogenation than other supported Ni catalysts. For those catalysts, the catalytic activity gradually decreases in the order of 10%Ni/SiO2-1a=10%Ni/SiO2–Al2O3 ≈2.2%Ru/Al2O3 ≈Raney Ni>1%Ru-10%Ni/Al2O3 >10%Ni/TiO2 >10%Ni/C>10%Ni/Al2O3 >1%Pd/Al2O3, slightly different from the descending order for the selectivity: 10%Ni/SiO2-1a>1%Ru-10%Ni/Al2O3 >10%Ni/C>10%Ni/Al2O3 >10%Ni/TiO2 >10%Ni/SiO2–Al2O3 >2.2%Ru/Al2O3 ≈1%Pd/Al2O3 >Raney Ni. For the titled reaction, the supported catalyst 10%Ni/SiO2-1a is the most active. Table 3 presents the effect of various solvents on the catalytic hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN over 10%Ni/SiO2-1a under 5.2MPa of H2 pressure, in which the tested solvents include methanol, dioxane, ethyl acetate, THF and cyclohexane. When methanol is used as the solvent, only 56.1mol% of 1,5-DNN is converted to 1,5-DAN at 220°C, without any detectable 1,5-DADHN. Other four solvents result in 100mol% conversion of 1,5-DNN; however, the selectivity for fully-hydrogenated 1,5-DADHN decreases in the sequence of THF (95.3%)>cyclohexane (91.2%)>dioxane (61.8%)>ethyl acetate (55.6%). It seems that the solvents with cyclic structure is beneficial to the hydrogenation of aromatic rings in 1,5-DNN, for which THF is preferred. This means that the co-adsorption of substrate and solvent on the catalyst surface affects the chemisorption of reaction species. As presented in Fig. 9A, the conversion of 1,5-DNN over 10%Ni/SiO2-1a is increased from 65.5 to 100mol% as the reaction temperature is increased from 110 to 190°C. Above reaction temperature of 190°C, the conversion of 100mol% is maintained. The selectivity for fully-hydrogenated 1,5-DADHN is only 6.8% at 110°C, which is gradually increased to 25.6% at 170°C and 50.5% at 190°C, rapidly to the maximum of 95.3% at 220°C, and then slightly reduced to 91.6% at 230°C. Fig. 9B exhibits the effect of the reaction time on the hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN over 10%Ni/SiO2-1a at 220°C. Within 1h, the conversion of 1,5-DNN is about 72.3mol%, which is rapidly increased to 94.9mol% in 2h, and to 100mol% in 4h, showing the induction period characteristic of this hydrogenation reaction. As the reaction time is prolonged to above 4h, the conversion of 100mol% is kept almost unchanged. The selectivity of fully-hydrogenated 1,5-DADHN is lower than 10.0% within 2h, which is rapidly increased to 79.7% in 4h, and to the maximum of 95.3% in 6h, and then slightly decreased to 90.2% in 8h. If the reaction time becomes too long, the formation of hydrocracked by-products will be enhanced. In the liquid phase hydrogenation, the hydrogen pressure is a very important parameter, as hydrogen serves as one of reactants. Fig. 9C shows the effect of the hydrogen pressure on the conversion of 1,5-DNN over 10%Ni/SiO2-1a at 220°C. The conversion of 1,5-DNN is only 69.7mol% under 2.0MPa of H2 pressure, which is increased to stable 100mol% at 4.0–6.4MPa. The selectivity for 1,5-DADHN is increased from 36.5% at 2.0MPa to the maximum of 95.3% at 5.2MPa, and then slightly decreased to 87.2% at 6.4MPa. Thus, the preferred H2 pressure is about 5.2MPa, considerably conducive to the adsorption of reactants on the catalyst surface and thereby the fast occurrence of full-hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DADHN. This implies that fully-hydrogenated products could be formed merely under a suitable H2 pressure. This dependence is in agreement with the observations during the hydrogenation of naphthalene [44,45]. 3.2.3 Effect of the silica source, modifier and Ni loading Table 4 list the reaction data obtained over three catalysts 10%Ni/SiO2-1, 10%Ni/SiO2-2 and 10%Ni/SiO2-3 prepared from three silica sources. Different silica sources really affect the catalytic activity of the resulting catalysts. Comparatively speaking, the conversion of 1,5-DNN decreases in the order of 100mol% (10%Ni/SiO2-1, aerosil-200 silica)=100mol% (10%Ni/SiO2-2, Ludox AS-40 colloidal silica)>98.6mol% (10%Ni/SiO2-3, Ludox HS-40 colloidal silica), in agreement with the variation for the 1,5-DADHN selectivity of 91.8% (10%Ni/SiO2-1)>87.0% (10%Ni/SiO2-2)>83.4% (10%Ni/SiO2-3), indicative of the key role of silica source. As shown in Fig. 5, uniformly fine particle sizes of 10%Ni/SiO2-1 originating from aerosil-200 silica are obviously smaller than those of 10%Ni/SiO2-2 and 10%Ni/SiO2-3, from which the high activity of the former catalyst is readily understandable. Four kinds of matters have been selected as the modifiers in the process of catalyst preparation, such as sesbania powder, activated carbon, n-octyltrimethyl ammonium bromide and glucose. As listed in Table 5 , the uses of sesbania powder and activated carbon as modifiers promote the selective production of fully-hydrogenated 1,5-DADHN with 100mol% conversion of 1,5-DNN. Particularly, the catalyst 10%Ni/SiO2-1a modified with sesbania powder can obtain the highest yield of 1,5-DADHN (95.3mol%); however, the addition of n-octyltrimethyl ammonium bromide and glucose decrease the yield of 1,5-DADHN as compared with unmodified 10%Ni/SiO2-1. This may be that the modification of sesbania powder and activated carbon assist to increase the BET surface areas and pore volumes of the resulting catalysts (in Table 1), beneficial to the diffusion and approach to active sites of 1,5-DNN reactant molecules. Nickel as an active component, a relatively cheap metal as compared with noble metals, has been widely applied in the catalytic hydrogenation reactions [46,47]. The loading amount of nickel has a great impact on the performance of the catalyst. In the present reaction, the effect of Ni loading on Ni/SiO2-1a has been carefully investigated and illustrated in Fig. 10A. When the Ni loading is 1wt%, the conversion of 1,5-DNN can only reach 56.9mol%; as the Ni loading slowly increases from 3 to 10wt%, the activity of the resulting catalyst is largely improved, with an increased conversion of 1,5-DNN from 89.2 to 100mol%. A further increase of the Ni loading to 15wt% will not make any further contribution. The selectivity for 1,5-DADHN is reduced in the order of 95.3% (10%Ni)>88.9% (15%Ni)>85.9% (5%Ni)>59.5% (3%Ni)>23.5% (1%Ni). The literature has disclosed the dependence of the catalytic hydrogenation of aromatic rings on the particle size of the supported metals [48]. However, in the present study it is difficult to distinguish the effect of the particle size from the Ni content, because the high loading of NiO has led to a large quantity of easily reducible NiO species, and a number of active metal Ni sites on the support beneficial to the hydrogenation of aromatic rings. Fig. 10B shows the effect of the catalyst amount on the catalytic hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN at 220°C under 5.2MPa of H2 pressure. Over 20mg of the catalyst (10%Ni/SiO2-1a), 87.8mol% of 1,5-DNN can be converted, with only 16.7% selectivity for fully-hydrogenated 1,5-DADHN. When the catalyst amount is increased to more than 50mg, 100mol% conversion of 1,5-DNN is realized. When the catalyst amount is varied from 20 to 100mg, the selectivity of 1,5-DADHN exhibits a gradual change in the sequence of 16.7% (20mg)<53.2% (50mg)<82.3% (70mg)<95.3% (100mg), in which 100mg is an optimal amount. With a continuous increase of the catalyst amount to 130mg, the selectivity for 1,5-DADHN shows a small drop to 89.7%, and that of heterolytic cleavage products is increased to 10.3%. This means that the excess catalyst does not favor the selective hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DADHN over 10%Ni/SiO2-1a. 3.2.4 Effect of the water amount on the catalytic hydrogenation Based on our experiments, it is found that the water amount takes a great impact on the catalytic full-hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DADHN. The selective hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN in THF is investigated by varying the water amount from 0 to 0.33g. As shown in Fig. 11A, the hydrogenation reaction in THF over 10%Ni/SiO2-1a without additional water can achieve 95.3mol% yield of fully-hydrogenated 1,5-DADHN within 6h. According to our calculations, if all the nitro groups in 1,5-DNN (added) are stoichiometrically reduced to amino groups, 0.33g of water will be generated, which does not exert any negative impact on the reaction itself. However, the external addition of additional water has evidently affected the conversion and selectivity. For example, the addition of 0.1g water drastically decreases the selectivity of 1,5-DADHN to 65.3%, but merely leads to a small drop of the conversion to 99.7mol%. Even with a continuous addition of the water amount to 0.33g, the conversion of 1,5-DNN can still maintain at the level of 93.2mol%; however, the selectivity to fully-hydrogenated 1,5-DADHN has been largely reduced to only 18.6%. This result is similar to that using methanol as reaction solvent (only 56.1mol% of conversion and no fully-hydrogenated 1,5-DADHN product). The solubility of organics and hydrogen in solvent and the solvent effects caused adsorption–desorption behavior on the surface of the catalyst has a great impact on the reaction rate. Thus, methanol and water have similar reaction properties, possibly because both solvents are protic. Apparently, external addition of additional water mainly suppresses the hydrogenation of naphthalene rings to bicyclohexyl rings, different from the promoting effects of the added water on some hydrogenation reactions reported in the literature [49–52]. As a comparison, the effect of the water amount on the catalytic hydrogenation of 1,5-DAN to 1,5-DADHN is discussed in Fig. 11B, in which 1,5-DAN is recognized as an intermediate from 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DADHN. It is noteworthy that no water is produced during the catalytic hydrogenation from 1,5-DAN to 1,5-DADHN. As 1,5-DAN is hydrogenated to 1,5-DADHN in THF at 220°C under 5.2MPa of H2 pressure, 100mol% conversion of 1,5-DAN and 94.9% selectivity for 1,5-DADHN are achieved. The extermal addition of water with 0.1–0.2g has exerted an appreciable influence, in which the conversion is kept at 100mol%, but the selectivity of 1,5-DADHN is slightly reduced to 92.5–93.0% (in Fig. 11B). However, once 0.25 or 0.33g of water is added to the reaction, the selectivity of fully-hydrogenated 1,5-DADHN is sharply reduced to 80.6 or 45.2%, although 100mol% of the conversion is still obtained. This implies that the addition of water in the hydrogenation from 1,5-DAN to 1,5-DADHN will promote the occurrence of side reactions inclusive of heterolytic crackings. With reference to the above-stated results, we can propose that the most likely reaction mechanism be surely involved in two main reactions, inclusive of the reductions from 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DAN, and from 1,5-DAN to 1,5-DADHN. However, once the reaction is initiated, these two reactions can simultaneously take place through a synergic route. Consequently, although 0.33g of water can be generated from the reduction of 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DADHN, it does not exert any negative effect on the reaction. Apart from this amount, the external addition of any additional water seriously decreases the selectivity of 1,5-DADHN. However, for the conversion from 1,5-DAN to 1,5-DADHN, the addition of even 0.1g water will notably affect the reaction process. This phenomenon is complicated and profound, possibly related to many factors, for which the researches in-depth are still ongoing. 3.3 Recycling studies The recycling uses of the catalyst 10%Ni/SiO2-1a in the hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DADHN have been carried out to monitor the recycling stability of the catalyst. As listed in Table 6 , the eight times reuses of 10%Ni/SiO2-1a do not appreciably decrease the conversion of 1,5-DNN and the selectivity for 1,5-DADHN. This could be ascribed to the strong interaction of the supported metallic nickel with the support as disclosed by the H2-TPR profiles, further inhibiting the leaching of metallic Ni species during the reaction. The conversion of 1,5-DNN shows only a small variation in the range of 97.2–100mol%, while the selectivity for fully-hydrogenated 1,5-DADHN has kept an inconspicuous fluctuation of around 93.4–95.3%. For the first recycle, ICP analyses of the reaction mixture and the used catalyst did detect the leaching of Ni from 10%Ni/SiO2-1a, leading to the reduction of the Ni content from 10 to 9.9wt%, possibly due to the leaching of soluble Ni species. For the latter seven recycles, no further leaching of Ni was detected. Correspondingly, the catalysts before and after use have also been characterized by Energy Dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy (EDX) and XRD (see Figs. S2 and S3), which show only a small reduction of the Ni content on the surface of the catalyst from 10.62 to 9.42wt% even after eight reuses. This study further reveals the recyclability and stability of the active catalyst 10%Ni/SiO2-1a for the titled reaction. 4 Conclusion This work has firstly reported highly efficient ‘one-step’ liquid phase hydrogenation of nitro-aromatic compounds with nitro groups and aromatic rings. The present study is focused on the catalytic full-hydrogenation of 1,5-dinitronaphathlene to 1,5-diaminodecahydronaphathlene over the supported Ni catalysts. Under optimal conditions, almost 100 mol% of the substrate conversion is obtained over 10%Ni/SiO2-1a with a high selectivity of the product up to 95.3%. Some factors affecting the reaction are revealed through conducting a number of reactions and wide characterizations. The addition of sesbania modifier has led to the increased BET surface area and pore volume from 289m2/g (0.38cm3/g) of 10%Ni/SiO2-1 to 312m2/g (0.45cm3/g) of 10%Ni/SiO2-1a. This is possible that the modification of sesbania powder can assist to increase the BET surface areas and pore volumes of the resulting catalysts, beneficial to the diffusion and approach to active sites of 1,5-DNN reactant molecules. The XPS results suggest that there is a net transfer of electrons towards Ni to increase the binding energy of Ni2p once the NiO oxide is reduced to metallic Ni with H2. The temperature of the first TPR reduction peak of the samples increases in the order of 10%Ni/SiO2-1a<10%Ni/SiO2-1<10%Ni/TiO2 <10%Ni/SiO2–Al2O3. The increase of the calcination temperature can gradually enhance the interaction of NiO with the support, further increasing the reduction temperature of NiO species. The reduction temperature of the supported Ni catalysts (e.g. 10%Ni/SiO2-1a) in the H2 flow exerts a notable impact on the hydrogenation activity. The negative effect of the water amount has been observed. The recycling studies have revealed the recyclability and stability of 10%Ni/SiO2-1a for the titled reaction. coredata.dc:description: A series of the supported nickel catalysts have been synthesized through impregnation, characterized by X-ray diffraction, N2 sorption measurement, temperature programmed H2 reduction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The morphology and particle size of catalysts are imaged by scanning electron microscope. The catalysts have efficiently catalyzed the one-step hydrogenation of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene to 1,5-diaminodecahydronaphthalene. The catalyst 10%Ni/SiO2-1a is the most active for the titled hydrogenation with 100mol% conversion and 95.3% selectivity, applicable for the catalytic one-step hydrogenation of nitro-aromatic compounds. The reducibility of NiO species on different supports has been carefully studied. Some factors such as the type of carriers, the addition of modifiers, the silica source, the Ni loading, the H2 pressure and the reaction temperature and time play important roles in controlling the hydrogenation. In addition, the negative effect of the water amount has been observed. The recycling tests reveal the recyclability and stability of the supported Ni catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis, structure and catalytic activity of the supported Ni catalysts for highly efficient one-step hydrogenation of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene to 1,5-diaminodecahydronaphthalene
